channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: Immigration Is on Agenda for Obama in Mexico
item.description: President Obama planned to discuss economic and trade matters, the drug war and immigration, the most delicate topic, when he meets with President Enrique Peña Nieto.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Bolivian President Expels U.S. Aid Agency
item.description: President Evo Morales suggested that the United States Agency for International Development had conspired against his leftist government.
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Havana Journal: On May Day in Havana, a Nod to Capitalism
item.description: On May Day in Havana, among the throngs of state employees marching was a novel and increasingly favored breed: private entrepreneurs and employees.
item.dc:creator: By VICTORIA BURNETT
item.media:description: The May Day march on Wednesday in Havana. This year joining the state workers were private-sector entrepreneurs and employees.

item.title: The Lede: Critics of Israel’s West Bank Occupation Say Calm Before New Violence Was an Illusion
item.description: Israelis opposed to the occupation of the West Bank argued that an 18-month pause between fatal attacks on Israelis there, which ended Tuesday, had created “an illusion of calm and stability.”
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers blocked the cameras of Israeli activists who were recording their activities in the occupied West Bank this month.

item.title: Nigerian Village’s Destruction Is Shown in Photos
item.description: Satellite images show 2,275 destroyed buildings in a Nigerian village, corroborating residents’ accounts that soldiers burned their homes, Human Rights Watch said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:credit: Pius Utomi Ekpei/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Nigerian soldier stands guard in Baga on Tuesday. As many as 200 civilians were killed in an assault there that survivors blamed on soldiers.

item.title: Irish Government Proposes Allowing Abortion in Emergencies
item.description: The Irish government has proposed legislation to allow abortion in cases where a threat exists to a woman’s life, including from suicide.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS DALBY

item.title: Older British Stars Caught Up in Operation Yewtree
item.description: An investigation into sexual offenses that may or may not have been committed decades ago has resulted in a flurry of arrests and has many people asking who will be next.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH LYALL

item.title: Besieged Syrian Leader Assad Makes Rare Appearance
item.description: President Bashar al-Assad’s visit to a power plant in the capital, Damascus, came after consecutive days of deadly bombings in the heart of his power base.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HWAIDA SAAD and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: In a photo released by the Syrian official news agency, SANA, President Bashar al-Assad of Syria, center, visited a Damascus power plant on Wednesday.

item.title: China Likely to Challenge U.S. Supremacy in East Asia, Report Says
item.description: But the report, by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, said American-Chinese interdependence would prevent China from trying to force the United States out.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: A Chinese commander adjusts the cap of a soldier in Beijing, ahead of a visit by President François Hollande of France in April.

item.title: China Cracks Down on Military LIcense Plates
item.description: Officials are cracking down on the abuse of privileges that come with a military license plate, in a bid to address public anger at the army.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:description: Chinese navy officers pose for photographs with the new, left, and old military car license plates in Hebei Province.

item.title: Greeks Stage General Strike Against Austerity
item.description: The protest came as workers around the world observed the international Labor Day with demonstrations and rallies, most of which, news reports said, went off quietly.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: A nationwide general strike on Wednesday to protest government austerity measures in Greece was called by the country’s two main labor unions.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In Amsterdam, the Golden Age of Museum Renovation
item.description: Just in time for coronation week, the Van Gogh Museum, the Rijksmuseum and the Stedelijk are all finally open again.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Vincent van Gogh's "Self-portrait," from 1887-1888, is on view at the newly reopened museum that bears his name.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 1
item.description: International Labor Day observed in India.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A rickshaw puller in Kolkata, West Bengal, carrying a passenger on a hand-pulled rickshaw, on International Labor Day, also known as International Workers' Day.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Dying Long Distance
item.description: One of the consequences of an expatriate life is separation from family and friends, and from the major life events that define families. How do you deal with the loss of a loved one when you’re on the other side of an ocean?
item.dc:creator: By JAN BENZEL

item.title: Roadside Bomb Kills 3 British Soldiers in Afghanistan
item.description: In other violence in Helmand Province, an Afghan government peace negotiator and two of his bodyguards were killed in an ambush, according to news reports.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In New Chinese Campaign, Concerns Over Morals and Corruption
item.description: With corruption and abuse of power rife in China, a new government campaign appears to be telling 80 million Communist Party members, “Clean up your act or else,” But how effective will it be?
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China, right, with President François Hollande of France, at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing last month.

item.title: India Ink: A Conversation With: Psychiatrist Dinesh Bhugra, Expert on Deviant Sexual Behavior
item.description: A psychiatrist on what drives certain people to sexually assault children.
item.dc:creator: By MALAVIKA VYAWAHARE

item.title: Letter from China: Allegiance, the Privilege of the Party
item.description: Politics in China are often viewed through the prism of party politics. But something far older and more powerful is at play: an ancient moral code of fidelity to a lord, or fealty.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Low-Cost Indonesian Airlines Keep Growing, Despite Troubling Record
item.description: The recent crash of a Lion Air flight off Bali last month came as the carrier ordered 234 planes for $24 billion, its second major expansion deal in three years.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: National Rescue Team, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rescuers at the crash site of a Lion Air plane off the Indonesian resort island of Bali last month.

item.title: China Data Confirm Slowdown in Factories
item.description: An official index showed a drop in growth for April, mirroring a report from the British bank HSBC.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: The Female Factor: The Face of the Gay Rights Movement
item.description: High-profile men have tightened their hold on the leadership as strategists, promoters, spokesmen and financiers.
item.dc:creator: By LUISITA LOPEZ TORREGROSA

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Echoes of Saddam’s War in Dilemma Over Syria’s Chemical Weapons
item.description: Western leaders want proof before taking action on Syria’s alleged use of chemical weapons. In an earlier conflict, they had the proof but did nothing.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: A Kurdish woman at a monument for the dead in Halabja.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Extinction Nears for China’s ‘River Pig,’ the Finless Porpoise
item.description: Six years ago the Baiji dolphin was declared functionally extinct in China’s Yangtze River. Its close relative, the finless porpoise, may die out in 10 years, conservationists say.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Urgent conservation work is needed if the finless porpoise, which lives in the Yangtze River, is not to die out like the Baiji dolphin did six years ago, says the WWF.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: May 1
item.description: Arrest in Bangladesh; Obama recommits to closing Guantánamo; cash in China; Berlin names streets for women; and Oslo runs out of trash.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers escorting Sohel Rana, owner of the building that collapsed in Bangladesh last week, into court on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Lawyer to Contest Congress Leader Sajjan Kumar’s Acquittal in 1984 Riots Case
item.description: After more than two decades of pursuing the case in court and several acquittals, lawyer for victim of riots says he won’t quit.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Congress party leader Sajjan Kumar in New Delhi on Aug. 9, 2005.
